all_paragraphs: If you want to work as a senior data scientist, you need to be familiar with different programming languages because of:

When you want to learn a new programming language it does not matter if you are new or an expert, we as humans are afraid of changes, mostly because we think it is hard. You have to invest time to find good resources, learn the new comment structure, and prepare your brain for the new language you want to learn. A Chinese proverb says:
Learning is a treasure that will follow its owner everywhere.
One type of treasure for us data scientists is learning a new programming language with a purpose. How we can convert the fear to a treasure? let me tell you how.

Many software engineers, during their bachelor or master courses, have to learn different programming language i.e., C#, C++, Python, R, Matlab, etc, based on their interest or the courses and the interest of the professors in the university. But for some people that want to start their career as a data scientist, programming is new. Like many of you, after completing my Ph.D., I decided to enter industry. I was surprised when seeing job applications that needed qualification like this:

During my master and Ph.D., I was using Matlab for doing data science projects as any researcher, I knew only a programming language that I used in my daily work. But, many organizations and job positions for data scientist projects prefer to use Python or R because they are open source and companies do not have to pay for a license. So, I started learning R.

Like everyone else, I thought that change was difficult, we also know how interesting it is to learn a new topic. I tried to figure out how to learn a new programming language, I recognized the 4 steps will help me:
Yes, if you want to learn it great, you have to start to create an application in the new language, as Tim Sanders is saying:
Education without application is just entertainment
If I wanted to get a job, I had to learn it great, so, I started to convert a project from Matlab to R. I recognized that:
When you have a focused workflow for learning, then you shouldn’t be afraid to learn new programming languages

I created the workflow and I converted the fear to a treasure, I learned a lot, did the first project, was happy and I got the job that I wanted to have. I was a senior data scientist that knows two analytics programs.
After two years of working with R and doing different analytics projects, I found it:
Here is a comparison between Matlab and R:
But after two years I decided to take on new challenges in a company whose common data science tool was Python.
When I interviewing for the new position I told the interviewer that I do not see any challenges in learning Python because I used a workflow that worked for me. I know:
there is no challenge in learning a new programming language, when you learned already some of them.

I applied the same workflow again, finding the best environment, a good book, an online course, and learn with a purpose or application. Yes, it worked again, the first day I took up my new position, during learning, I wrote my projects in Python, with Anaconda and Pycharm. If you are a data scientist and work with Python, you know, it has roughly all the things that you need for doing a great project and how enjoyable python programming is.

The main benefit I got from these changes was at a time when I was taking over an old project that was written in R and I was able to contribute to the project. Nowadays, I am working on a project that the data collection part of it, is done in Matlab and my customer is doing simulation in Matlab, I do not have a problem with their source code and I am leading the data science part of it. Also, I sometimes mix Python and R to do a good project when I see restrictions in a Python package. This mixed situation of R and Python helps me to create highly precise and trustworthy data science products.
